Kissingers realpolitik was largely about avoiding the worst case scenario by embracing the second-worst scenario.   There are legitimate and real critiques here: sometimes this meant engaging in support of hideous activity to avoid creation of Soviet satellites (Indonesia vs. East Timor), sometimes it meant getting it right in the short term to get it wrong in the long-term (opening China), sometimes it meant ignoring human rights abuses in order to foster other priorities (Soviet dissident Jews). There have been serious critiques on these and other issues from both the Left and the Right.  But the most fundamental ideological critique of Kissinger -- that foreign policy isnt a series of choices between awful alternatives, and that there is a "family of nations" in which "international law" governs; that "blowback" against American foreign policy is the chief driver of foreign policy problems, as though no other country or polity has independent agency and priorities of its own; that America can have clean hands or that Amercan isolationism is a true option in a multipolar world -- is totally wrong.
